pros: Wonderful leadership great place to learn
cons: There is 0 bad about this company just a few bad folks that want it there way but really are not good at what they do!

review_title: Toxic, unhealthy work environment driven by CEO ego - agency suffers mission drift, revolving staff door
pros: The mission at the heart of the organization is noble
cons: The organization is so deferential to entry and mid-career level staff resulting in significant mission drift. Each employee comes to the organization with their own 'idea' of what the organization ought to do. Combine this with a complete lack of leadership by the CEO and the result is a fractured, unhealthy and toxic workspace. The CEO has demonstrated she's more interested in increasing her public profile than the greater good of the PATIENTS the agency serves. The HR team is ineffective at executing organizational improvements. The health center harbored a problematic medical professional with a questionable past and appalling behavior. Colleagues that would otherwise be aligned and collaborative were turned against once another, adding fuel to an already-burning firestorm: saboteurs around every corner. Trillium exhibits nothing more than a modern-day Machiavellian culture with a revolving door of managers and leaders. The HR leadership will hire and re-hire the same roles, firing, laying off staffers but NEVER fixing the root cause: the people making decisions. We don't even have the character count to discuss the mis-spendings of the CEO. For an organization so active in fundraising it looks the other way as it employs an assistant to drive the CEO to the office and back home. Financial oversight is a SIGNIFICANT issue. All of this chaos / disruption directly impacts the quality of service the agency provides communities in need of equitable and affirming health care and specialized services. The front-line medical teams are amazing, in spite of a FAILING organization. This health care center is flawed to the point of damaging colleagues professional growth, reputation and mission commitment. The sad irony is that for a center focused on the health & well being of its community it remains damaging and unhealthy to the very community it employs.

pros: None! Absolutely terrible place to work.
cons: Toxic culture and leadership encourages the behavior. The exception is if you are part of the LGBTQ+ community or a person of color.

review_title: A Good Company to work for!
pros: Fringe benefits, generous PTO, Family Friendly.
cons: Salary, specific leaders, and siloed work spaces.

review_title: Excellent Benefits, Toxic Culture in Care Management
job_title: Health Homes Care Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: Excellent benefits including HSA, FSA, and PTO. Great services for clients and you can build relationships with the people you are helping. Other areas of the organization seemed much less toxic and enjoyable.
cons: The culture in care management was very toxic. Managers and employees were overworked and felt the pressure of upper level management. The amount of work was difficult to keep up with and the amount of paperwork and documentation was daunting.

pros: Very skilled staff. Lots of lived experiences. Many resources for staff and clients. Awesome trainings, lots of positive learning, and opportunities of going to conferences out of town. Raises and bonuses. Meeting people from all over the world. Cultural Committees. Lunch & Learns.
cons: Health homes / Care Management Leadership provided Limited support. Manager had Poor accountability. Negative language and verbal abuse of manager in the department. Used negative labeling words. Triggered people making supervisors cry.

pros: working with the patients and clients
cons: working with some of the staff

review_title: An agency in flux and often times chaotic management.
pros: I worked there when it was AIDS Care after the merger/take over of AIDS Rochester.  The best part of the job was working with clients and assisting them in their needs and working with staff that had a common goal.  Benefits were very good though salary did not adequately compensate for the duties of many positions.
cons: Terminations were a common occurrence. All the associate directors who were employees of AIDS Rochester for many years were terminated in my department and their replacements were terminated within six months as well.  Many former staff left after the merger/take over.  You could be doing fine one day and then the next day were being criticized for your work.  It was very much like riding a roller coaster ride with no consistent supervision.  Concrete suggestions or feedback were not received well by management.  The atmosphere supported trying to find fault in others' performance rather than positive feedback or constructive feedback.  The agency was very much in flux with constant changes in policies and agendas, and staff suffered as a result.  Departments were often at odds with each other especially with the department I worked in.  Focus seemed to be on who knew best rather than working together as a team.

job_title: Prevention/Sexual Health Educator in Rochester, NY
pros: Great no issues layed back environment

Trillium Health is a positive presence in the community with a plethora of services that are provided to the Rochester and surrounding areas, and I am proud to be a part of it.  Patients have said the staff/employees are warm, welcoming and not judgmental. The mission and vision of the company are a positive reinforcement of what this company does for the community.    

The company is growing and there is a lot of growth potential for employees.


There are excellent benefits, room for growth and a positive and supportive atmosphere.
cons: With any company there is always room for improvement.  I have an open door policy to talk to my supervisor about anything.  Trillium Health is always working on ways to improve and to make the company a great place to work (which it is).

review_title: Appears nothing has changed with a divisive management
pros: Working with clients, meeting them where they were at in life, and making a best effort to improve their health and quality of life.
cons: It is sad to see from other reviews that nothing has changed.  I had over a two decade tenure when AIDS Rochester merged with Community Health Network, became AIDS Care and now Trillium Health.  It was well known that the personnel polices of the agency we were merging with had much to be desired.  It appears the divisive environment continues.  The Board of Directors has a clear stake in the management of this agency and are failing at their task.
